document_data.caption: A female [[adept]] of the [[College of Shaping Magics]] holds a rag and string golem.
document_data.name: Rag and string golem
document_data.size1e: Small<ref group="note" name="size">No size was provided for this creature, but based on its described height it would be classified as a size small.
document_data.alignment1e: [[Neutral]]<ref group="note" name="alignment">No alignment was provided for this creature, but golems in 1{{st}} edition were typically [[neutral]]-aligned.
document_data.language: The primary language of its creator.
document_data.mainbody: '''Rag and string golems''' were a type of [[golem]] that were developed, and whose construction were taught by, the [[College of Shaping Magics]],
document_data.Description: As their name implied, these [[construct]]s were crafted from rags and string. They had a [[humanoid]] shape and stood around {{SIrange|1|2|ft|long=yes}} tall.
document_data.Behavior:
These golems were very intelligent, being capable of receiving and carrying out very complicated instructions without flaw. They could even modify the wording of their orders in order to better achieve the intent of their instructed goal.

Rag and string golems were faithful to their creator and would only serve their orders. Though their creator could order them to serve someone else for a day.
document_data.Abilities: These golems could be imbued with knowledge of some [[spell]]s, though not [[ritual]]s, and if imbued with more than one spell they had to be from the same [[school of magic]].This section uses the term "college," which comes from the tabletop role-playing game that ''[[The Shattered Statue]]'' was written to be cross-compatible with — [[wikipedia:en:DragonQuest|''DragonQuest'']] — which are not to be confused with the university introduced in that adventure module, the [[College of Shaping Magics]]. ''DragonQuest's'' concept of "colleges of magic" are equivalent to the [[school of magic|schools of magic]] of D&D.

Society.Languages: Unlike most golems, these were capable of not only understanding their creator's primary language, but also conversing in it.
